question: A) In the app, what does a steep slope of the SWRC indicate in the \u03b8–h space? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Steeper SWRCs reflect abrupt desaturation typical of sandy soils.
error: ❌ A steep slope suggests sharp drainage and uniform pore sizes, not gradual changes.

question: A) When comparing two datasets in the app, what might cause one soil to have a higher effective field capacity than another? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. eFC increases with lower PWP, higher FC, and greater pore volume.
error: ❌ eFC is not improved by a very low n value; that typically flattens the curve.

question: A) How does the \u03b1 parameter affect the position of the retention curve? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Exactly. \u03b1 controls how early drainage begins and reflects pore entry pressure.
error: ❌ \u03b1 has a key influence on suction behavior, not conductivity.

question: A) Which conclusions can be drawn by comparing two contrasting SWRCs? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Well done. These comparisons highlight how retention behavior varies with texture.
error: ❌ Remember: FC and PWP are both texture-dependent and don't scale linearly.

question: A) When comparing relative permeability curves derived from two soils, what trends typically appear? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Coarse soils desaturate and lose conductivity rapidly. The relationship is nonlinear in all cases.
error: ❌ Fine-textured soils typically retain water longer but do not preserve high relative permeability.

question: A) What conclusions can be drawn when both datasets have identical \u03b8_r and \u03b8_s values, but different n and \u03b1? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Even with equal saturation limits, α and n shape the curve and thus affect FC and PWP.
